description: Deep analysis of how ideas develop through contradiction and resolution. Reveals the hidden tensions that drive discourse, how opposites secretly depend on each other, and what gets preserved or destroyed when conflicts resolve. Uses sophisticated dialectical methods from Hegel, Marx, and critical theory but outputs in plain language anyone can understand.
researcher_question: What contradictions drive this discourse, and how do they work themselves out?

key_tensions.name: string (evocative name like 'The Innovation-Regulation Standoff')
key_tensions.what_clashes: string (plain language description of the conflict)
key_tensions.is_this_acknowledged: boolean (do authors realize this tension exists?)

positions_in_play.name: string (the position as a noun phrase)
positions_in_play.what_it_secretly_needs: string (what it depends on but won't admit)

what_gets_preserved_and_destroyed.what_was_negated: string (position or element that was overcome)

attempted_resolutions.name: string (evocative name)
attempted_resolutions.the_synthesis_move: string (how it claims to resolve the tension)

what_cant_be_thought.what_is_excluded: string (the suppressed third, the unthinkable option)
what_cant_be_thought.why_it_cant_appear: string (what about the discourse blocks it)

totality_and_fragments.claimed_totality: string (what claims to be the whole)

ideology_critique.immanent_critique: string (how to critique it using its own standards)

cross_document_dialectics.the_real_stakes: string (what the debate is really about)

nodes.id: string (any entity ID: T{N}, POS{N}, BIN{N}, etc.)
nodes.type: tension | position | binary | synthesis | contradiction | exclusion | mediation | negation | movement | ideology
nodes.label: string (short display name, 2-5 words)

edges.relationship: opposes | synthesizes | sublates | negates | mediates | produces | depends_on | excludes | contradicts | enables
edges.label: string (optional edge label)

extraction.core_question: What contradictions drive this discourse, and how do they work themselves out?
extraction_steps: READ FOR THE TENSIONS: What positions are in conflict? Don't just note disagreements - find genuine contradictions where both sides have a point but can't both be right
MAP THE POSITIONS: For each side of a tension, identify what it claims, what it gets right, and what it secretly depends on from its opponent
FIND THE BINARIES: What either/or distinctions structure the discourse? Which term is privileged? What third option gets excluded?
TRACE SUBLATION ATTEMPTS: Where does someone try to resolve a tension? What gets preserved? What gets destroyed? Does it actually work?
IDENTIFY CONTRADICTIONS: Where do positions contradict themselves? Where do they say one thing and do another? Where do their premises conflict with their conclusions?
MAP EXCLUSIONS: What positions literally cannot be thought within this discourse? What's the 'constitutive outside'?
FIND MEDIATIONS: What concepts, institutions, or practices connect opposed terms? How do they work?
TRACE DIALECTICAL MOVEMENT: Is there progression? Regression? Circular repetition? Spiral development?
IDENTIFY MASTER-SLAVE DYNAMICS: Who depends on whom? What does the dominant position need from what it dominates?
CRITIQUE TOTALITIES: What claims to be 'the whole picture'? What does it exclude?

key_fields.tension_id: The core unit - genuine contradictions, not mere disagreements
key_fields.sublation_id: Track what gets preserved and destroyed in resolutions

extraction.special_instructions: CRITICAL: A dialectical analysis is not just finding disagreements. Look for genuine contradictions where each side has real validity but they cannot both be true. The best dialectical analysis shows how opposites secretly depend on each other.

consolidation_rules: TENSION CONSOLIDATION: Merge equivalent tensions across documents - same conflict, different vocabulary
POSITION MAPPING: Build the full landscape of positions across the corpus
BINARY ARCHAEOLOGY: Identify the underlying binaries that structure multiple tensions
SUBLATION TRACKING: Have any tensions been resolved across the corpus? Partially? Not at all?
CONTRADICTION AGGREGATION: Which contradictions recur? Which are unique?
EXCLUSION PATTERNS: What consistently cannot be thought across documents?
DIALECTICAL PROGRESS: Is the discourse moving toward resolution or stuck?
Never mention Hegel, Marx, or dialectics: Lead with the insight, hide the method
curation.special_instructions: Focus on showing movement and development, not just static oppositions. The goal is to reveal how the discourse is working through its contradictions - or failing to.

id_examples.to: Tension: Can't have maximum innovation AND maximum safety
Saying 'safety first' while cutting safety budgets
What survived the AI Ethics Wave

concretization.naming_guidance: Use evocative, plain-language names that capture the drama of the conflict. Avoid academic jargon.

semantic_visual_intent.concept_description: The dynamic process by which contradictions generate movement and transformation. Not just 'there are opposing positions' but HOW opposition drives change through thesis-antithesis-synthesis movement, where contradictions are preserved-and-overcome (aufgehoben).

visual_grammar.essence: The visual must show MOVEMENT and TRANSFORMATION - how positions don't just oppose each other but generate new positions through their conflict

key_visual_elements.encoding: Directed flow showing thesis challenged by antithesis resolved in synthesis

key_visual_elements.purpose: Show where genuine contradictions exist (not just differences)
key_visual_elements.encoding: Tension lines, opposing arrows, or force vectors showing incompatibility
Synthesis nodes that visually contain/incorporate elements from both thesis and antithesis

key_visual_elements.purpose: Show ascending movement to higher synthesis
key_visual_elements.encoding: Vertical arrangement or spiral showing progression from lower to higher resolutions
Pulsing, jagged, or incomplete elements showing ongoing conflict

anti_patterns: static_position_map - Just showing where different positions 'are' without showing movement
venn_overlap_diagram - Suggests compatibility rather than productive contradiction
radial_category_wheel - No sense of dialectical progression or levels
design_principles: MOVEMENT IS ESSENTIAL - Dialectics is dynamic; the visual must show transformation, not just positions
CONTRADICTION GENERATES - Opposition is not just difference; it is the engine of change
SYNTHESIS IS NOT COMPROMISE - The higher unity preserves the truth of both moments while overcoming their limitations
LEVELS MATTER - Dialectical movement often spirals upward to more comprehensive syntheses
SOME CONTRADICTIONS REMAIN - Not everything is resolved; show active tensions

semantic_visual_intent.gemini_semantic_prompt:
You are visualizing DIALECTICAL STRUCTURE from a philosophical analysis.

This is NOT a concept map showing that different positions exist. This is a DIALECTICAL DIAGRAM showing how contradictions drive transformation.

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS:
1. Show THESIS to ANTITHESIS to SYNTHESIS movement with clear directional flow
2. Mark CONTRADICTIONS as genuine incompatibilities (not just differences)
3. Show SYNTHESIS as containing/preserving elements of both thesis and antithesis (not as a compromise or middle ground)
4. Use VERTICAL or SPIRAL arrangement to show dialectical progression to higher levels
5. Distinguish RESOLVED contradictions (synthesized) from UNRESOLVED tensions (still active)
6. Identify the FOUNDATIONAL CONTRADICTION that drives the whole dialectic

WHAT NOT TO DO:
- Do NOT create a static map of positions without movement
- Do NOT show thesis and antithesis as simply 'different views'
- Do NOT make synthesis look like averaging or compromise
- Do NOT use a flat radial layout - dialectics has levels/progression

The goal: Someone looking at this should SEE the dialectical movement - how contradictions generate new positions, which syntheses resolve which tensions, and where contradictions remain active.

recommended_forms.name: Dialectical Spiral
recommended_forms.when_to_use: Default for showing thesis-antithesis-synthesis progression through multiple levels
recommended_forms.gemini_template: Create a spiral or ascending diagram showing dialectical movement. Each turn of the spiral shows: (1) a THESIS position, (2) its ANTITHESIS that contradicts it, (3) the SYNTHESIS that preserves-and-overcomes both. Use upward movement to show progression to more comprehensive positions.

recommended_forms.name: Contradiction Force Field
recommended_forms.when_to_use: When focusing on active tensions and their relative strengths
recommended_forms.gemini_template: Create a force field diagram showing contradictions as opposing forces. Position contradicting elements on opposite sides with tension lines between them. Use visual weight to show strength of contradiction. Show resolved contradictions differently from active ones.

recommended_forms.name: Sublation Tree
recommended_forms.when_to_use: When showing how multiple lower contradictions feed into higher syntheses
recommended_forms.gemini_template: Create a tree structure where leaves are thesis/antithesis pairs and internal nodes are syntheses that sublate them. The root represents the highest synthesis. Use visual containment to show how synthesis preserves what it overcomes.

style_affinity.rationale: Dialectical content is philosophical and benefits from humanistic, crafted visualization that honors complexity
